channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: In Full: JPMorgan's Dimon on Economic Risks, Federal Reserve, China Business
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. CEO Jamie Dimon says he can’t rule out that the US economy will fall into stagflation as the country faces huge risks from both geopolitics, deficits and price pressures. Dimon also says the firm is "a long-term investor" in China and discusses his views on the Federal Reserve's policymaking. He speaks to Haslinda Amin on the sidelines of the JPMorgan Global China Summit in Shanghai. (Source: Bloomberg)

media:content.media:description: JPMorgan Chase & Co Photographer: Scott Eells/Bloomberg

item.title: JPMorgan Is Committed to China for Long Term, Dimon Says
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. Chief Executive Officer Jamie Dimon said his firm is committed to long-term investment in China, despite frailties between the governments of the world’s two biggest economies.
item.dc:creator: Cathy Chan, Haslinda Amin

item.title: Asian Shares Drop, Treasuries Steady After Selloff: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian shares fell and Treasuries steadied after a selloff sparked by concerns about a proposed tax-cut bill that threatened to enlarge the US deficit.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

item.title: JPMorgan CEO Dimon Says Fed 'Is Doing the Right Thing' to Wait and See
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. Chief Executive Officer Jamie Dimon says the Federal Reserve is "doing the right thing to kind of wait and see before they decide." Dimon tells Bloomberg Television that even though the US economy "has been doing well," policymakers need to "worry about the future." He speaks to Haslinda Amin on the sidelines of the JPMorgan Global China Summit in Shanghai. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Dimon Warns of US Stagflation Risk, Says Fed Is Right to Hold
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. chief Jamie Dimon said he can’t rule out the US economy will fall into stagflation as the country faces huge risks from geopolitics, deficits and price pressures.
item.dc:creator: Ambereen Choudhury, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: Jamie Dimon in Shanghai. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Southern Greek Islands Hit by 6.1-Magnitude Earthquake
item.description: ATHENS, Greece (AP) — A 6.1 magnitude earthquake shook southern Greek islands early Thursday.

item.title: Private Equity Deal Rush Shows Lenders Are Losing Their Star Billing
item.description: A flurry of recent buyouts has seen PE firms paying most of the purchase price, a long way from the industry’s heyday when debt was by far the biggest element.
item.dc:creator: Claire Ruckin

media:content.media:description: The building, left, that houses the Thoma Bravo private equity firm office at 830 Brickell Plaza in Miami, Florida, US, on Wednesday, March 5, 2025. Since the current iteration of Thoma Bravo was founded in 2008, it's been involved in roughly a fifth of all private equity buyouts in the sector as measured by value, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

item.title: Oil Holds Drop on US Stockpile Build and Wider Market Selloff
item.description: Oil steadied after a decline as higher US stockpiles reinforced worries about an oversupplied market, and wider financial markets eased.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin

media:content.media:description: The Deer Park Complex oil refinery and petrochemical plant, owned by Petroleos Mexicanos (PEMEX), in Houston, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 8, 2025. Some 40% of the crude oil processed at US refineries is imported, and Canada and Mexico, the No. 1 and No. 2 foreign suppliers of oil to the US, respectively, together deliver more than two-thirds of that oil. Photographer: Mark Felix/Bloomberg

item.title: Bitcoin Tops $111,000 for First Time as US Optimism Lifts Crypto
item.description: Bitcoin surpassed $111,000 for the first time to reach a record high, with traders increasingly bullish on the prospects of the original cryptocurrency amid mounting institutional demand.
item.dc:creator: Suvashree Ghosh, Sidhartha Shukla

media:content.media:description: A Bitcoin logo inside a cryptocurrency exchange in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday, March 9, 2022. Bitcoin dropped back below $40,000, erasing almost all the gains sparked by optimism about U.S. President Joe Biden’s executive order to put more focus on the crypto sector.

item.title: Gold Gains as Weak Bond Auction Highlights US Fiscal Concerns
item.description: Gold strengthened for a fourth day, as investors pushed back against US President Donald Trump’s tax-cut plan and growing fiscal deficit by driving long-range US Treasury yields to near a two-decade high.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie

item.title: Top Indian Oil Producer’s Quarterly Earnings Miss Estimates
item.description: State-run Oil and Natural Gas Corp.’s quarterly profit missed estimates as crude oil prices slumped and production from aging fields remained subdued.
item.dc:creator: Rakesh Sharma

item.title: Won Touches Seven-Month High on Report of Currency Talks With US
item.description: The South Korean won climbed to a seven-month high late Wednesday after local media reported the direction of the currency was discussed during trade talks with the US.
item.dc:creator: Jaehyun Eom

item.title: EQT-Owned Fitness Passport Seeks A$500 Million Loan for Payout
item.description: Swedish private equity firm EQT-backed health and fitness membership program Fitness Passport is seeking a A$500 million ($322 million) syndicated loan, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Chien Mi Wong

item.title: Indian Short Bonds Are on a Roll Betting on Dividend Windfall
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Ashutosh Joshi

item.title: New Zealand Budget 2025: Winners and Losers
item.description: New Zealand Finance Minister Nicola Willis had billed Thursday’s budget as a sober affair that would contain “no unicorns, no rainbows.”
item.dc:creator: Ainsley Thomson

item.title: India Wheat Crop Seen Hitting Record, Allaying Import Fears
item.description: India’s wheat output, which was threatened by the second-warmest February in over a century, is likely to be a bumper one this year as favorable weather during the crucial grain-filling stage improved yields.
item.dc:creator: Pratik Parija

media:content.media:description: India’s production is expected to hit a record 117 million tons, the US Department of Agriculture forecasts.

item.title: Private Credit Funds Target Billions in Retail Demand From Asia
item.description: From Singapore to Japan and Australia, fund managers in Asia are looking to unlock billions of dollars for private credit from the last untapped pocket: retail investors.
item.dc:creator: Megawati Wijaya

item.title: Bessent, Kato Confirm Existing FX Views, Avoid Talking Levels
item.description: US and Japanese finance chiefs confirmed existing currency views and did not discuss foreign exchange levels during a meeting in Canada, sending the yen briefly lower as markets wound back expectations for a more aggressive stance.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not.

item.title: Indonesia Set for More Rate Cuts on Growth View, Analysts Say
item.description: An improving market sentiment will pave the way for Indonesia’s central bank to better balance its pro-growth stance with ensuring stability in the financial markets, according to analysts.
item.dc:creator: Prima Wirayani, Eduard Gismatullin

item.title: Ultra Rich Wanted More China Exposure Before Trade War, UBS Says
item.description: Many of the world’s richest family offices were planning to ramp up their investments in China despite the looming threat of a global trade war, according to a survey of UBS Group AG clients.
item.dc:creator: David Ramli, Yoojung Lee

item.title: Bond Market Warns Trump, Congress on Dangers of Swelling Deficit
item.description: In the world’s biggest bond market, investors are pushing back against President Donald Trump’s tax-cut plan.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Liz Capo McCormick, Ye Xie

media:content.media:description: The White House and the US Treasury building in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, Feb. 24, 2025. Elon Musk’s demand that more than two million federal employees defend their work is facing pushback from other powerful figures in the Trump administration, in a sign that the billionaire’s brash approach to overhauling the government is creating division.

item.title: Chief Future Officer: Matt Skaruppa, Duolingo Chief Financial Officer
item.description: Chief Financial Officers now play a critical role in shaping corporate strategy and positioning organizations to meet future challenges. This episode profiles Duolingo CFO Matt Skaruppa, who has positioned the world's most popular language-learning app for a new phase of growth powered by AI. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Duolingo's Growth Formula Blends Engagement, AI
item.description: Duolingo has become the world's most popular language learning app. On Bloomberg Chief Future Office, CFO Matt Skaruppa tells Tim Stenovec how investments in design and advances in AI have combined to supercharge the company's global growth. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Why Duolingo Won't Add More Ads
item.description: Language learning app Duolingo could raise revenue by showing more advertisements to users of its free product. But the company's focus on long-term thinking over short-term results has led CEO Luis Von Ahn and CFO Matt Skaruppa to resist the temptation. They explain their reasoning to Tim Stenovec on Bloomberg Chief Future Officer. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Ringgit May Gain Most in Southeast Asia on Exporter Conversion
item.description: Malaysia’s ringgit stands to gain the most among its Southeast Asian peers if the nation’s exporters convert their overseas earnings to the local currency, thanks to the nation’s outsized foreign-currency deposits.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Wong

media:content.media:description: Malaysian hundred ringgit banknotes at a currency exchange store in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Friday, March. 1, 2024. Policymakers have stepped up their rhetoric to rein in the local currency’s fall after it reached the weakest level since the height of the Asian financial crisis in 1998 last week.

item.title: StanChart on 'Buy America' Trade, Outlook for Treasury Yields
item.description: Standard Chartered’s Audrey Goh speaks on Bloomberg's The Asia Trade about the recent spike in US bond yields, driven partly by concerns over the sustainability of US fiscal policies. Despite the ongoing market turmoil, Goh remains optimistic about the near-term outlook for US equities to rebound and notes that market volatility is trending lower. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Sony Life Mulls Selling Japan Bonds to Avoid Writing Down Losses
item.description: Sony Life Insurance will take measures, including the sale of government bonds it holds, to avoid writedowns in the event domestic interest rates keep rising.
item.dc:creator: Masahiro Hidaka

item.title: Treasuries Vie for Demand With Japan’s Bonds, Deutsche Says
item.description: US Treasuries are facing increased competition from Japanese bonds, where rising yields are making the notes more attractive for local buyers, according to Deutsche Bank AG.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill

item.title: Rio Seeks to Almost Double Bauxite Output From Queensland Mine
item.description: Rio Tinto Group is conducting early works and final studies to potentially almost double bauxite production from its Amrun project in far north Queensland by 2029.
item.dc:creator: Jason Scott

media:content.media:description: Red dirt on safety hats at the Gudai-Darri iron ore mine operated by the Rio Tinto Group in the Pilbara region of Western Australia, Australia, on Tuesday, June 21, 2022. Gudai-Darri, with an annual capacity of 43 million tons, is expected to increase iron ore production volumes and improve product mix from the Pilbara from the second half of this year, according to a company statement. Photographer: Carla Gottgens/Bloomberg

item.title: Ryan Reynolds’ Ad Firm MNTN, Holders Raise $187 Million in IPO
item.description: Connected TV advertising platform MNTN Inc. and some of its shareholders raised $187 million in an initial public offering priced at the top of a marketed range.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes
